evidence.text:
Person A: Paper towels - bad for the earth. Now, let’s examine the wound... Huh, maybe it needs stitches. What do you think?
Person B: Yeah - I mean, no -

Person A: Good. I think that’s good. Brave man. Potent.
Person A: Oh no, I got it on the couch. Paper towel. Let me know if it doesn’t come out. You should get that checked out.

Person A: Mine’s a war zone. Can I look around?
Person B: Be my - go ahead.

Person B: The answer should be clear to you! Whom else would I love but the most beautiful woman in the world? Of course! The most beautiful of all women! The most captivating, the most intelligent...it's perfectly transparent. I have no illusions. Sometimes in the blue shadows of evening, I give way to tender feelings. I go into a garden, smelling the fragrance of spring with my poor monstrous nose, and watch a man and a woman strolling together in the moonlight. I think how much I, too, would like to be walking arm in arm with a woman, under the moon. I let myself be carried away, I forget myself - and then I suddenly see the shadow of my profile on the garden wall.

Person A: You have this teeny blackhead and I’m dying to get at it.
Person A: Your skin is very oily. I have a good cream for that. Got a tissue? Ah, I see.

Person A: Would you kill yourself?
Person B: I don’t know. Maybe. Depends on the circumstances.
Person A: Don’t say maybe. Say no.
Person B: Would you?

Person A: I just feel embarrassed talking about - especially when it’s still in progress. I call myself a writer, but it’s - it’s sort of aspirational. I mean, I do write. I’ve done a few translations of this Italian - I - he’s nobody, you wouldn’t know him. I won an award for it. Small, but...but I’m trying to write my first original play. I’m still figuring it out. Gee, you probably want your typewriter back.
Person B: Throw it out for all I give a shit.
Person A: I wouldn’t throw it out. At the very least, it makes me look like a writer. Its presence mocks me.
Person B: Inspires you.
Person B: I’d like to come see your play when it’s all done.

Person A: What the hell was that?
Person A: What the fuck? Lot of weird things happening tonight.
Person B: Is he on the call sheet?

Person B: It’s a prototype.
Person A: A prototype of...what?
Person B: For the face...the eventual... we’ll use makeup, I don’t know, however you wanna do it.
Person B: I don’t think we can afford makeup. This is an off-broadway production. Do I know you? You sound familiar. Can you take off that mask, please?
Person B: Where did you get that mask?

Person A: The question is, do you cast someone with a condition, even if he’s not the best fit? Is it wrong to cast someone because of their disfigurement? Exploitative even? Will people come to gawk? Where is the ethical line? It’s funny... Edward, he has an awkwardness in his own skin, so, it’s kind of brilliant in a way - seeing you - who looks like- you, and you’re not yourself, you’ve got this mask, this other persona, and there’s this dissonance...it clicked - for me - it was strangely affecting. It was like I saw my creation come to life.
Person B: You might need to convince them.
Person A: I don’t have to convince anyone. It’s my play, pal.
Person A: Hi, Mr. Sablosky.
Person A: You don’t want to look at me?
Person B: You look ridiculous!
Person A: How do you know what kind of experience he’s had?
Person B: I think I know my own character’s “backstory,” thank you very much.
Person A: Great idea. Guy, talk like Oswald.

Person A: Sure you can. ’ello matey.
Person B: ‘ello matey.
Person B: Yeah, and you called me a prima donna. But, oh, if Oswald says it...

Person A: I don’t know. He’s just...Edward. Look, you wanted more lines. You said it yourself.
Person A: Come on.

Person A: Well, I’ve been thinking about - and to your credit, Guy, you were right - and Oswald too - the suicide was...ludicrous. This wasn’t meant to be a tragic love story. Why can’t they be happy? And Oswald and I were talking about Beauty and the Beast, and how in the end, he becomes a beautiful prince.

Person B: I don’t understand why he transforms. How is that possible?
Person A: He doesn’t transform, not literally.
Person B: So I’m the idealized version of Oswald?
Person B: Whereas Oswald has a photographic memory.
Person B: Well, he’s been giving me feedback and...
Person B: They’re talking about you like you’re a beast!

Person A: I’m not going home. Have a drink. Don’t be mopey.
Person A: That’s not my problem. Come or go, it’s up to you.

Person B: So, do we fancy a flat like this perhaps?
Person B: I’ll miss you most of all, darling.
Person B: It’s a long story. We met this woman, when we were -

Person A: What about your career?
Person B: I’ve accomplished everything I ever wanted. I’m ready for the next phase.
